comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Bing's Bird's-eye view is swingable-roundable (technical term) and you can clearly see the unchanged porch I've noted on the photo above.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Looking at the rifles and equipment the troops are using they are clearly pre- WW1.  They are wearing the old "fatigues" some of which were a manure brown colour (being polite on a family show!) and which sometimes were bleached almost white from usage and washing.  The rifle has a long muzzle protruding from the muzzle end of the stock whereas for the majority of WW1 the rifle in use was the Lee-Enfield Mark ii which had a much shorter muzzle.  The pouches they are wearing on their belts are leather with a leather belt and once more by 1914 the vast majority of troops were wearing canvas webbing belts and pouches.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think the notch at the front of the stock means (based only on wikipedia) that the NCO is carrying a Lee rifle, maybe a Lee-Enfield? Any psychopathic gun-nuts care to comment? [Edit: crossed with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] here - true that the barrel doesn't look Lee-Enfield-ish]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Thank you for keeping it clean as we're broadcasting before the watershed!

Should we be going for earlier than 1910, then? Have learned to be wary about dating on basis of uniforms, given that you've all said again and again that uniforms were re-used long after their "official" date...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Lee metford would be more likely, though it looks more like a Martini Henry from what I can see of it. It's way too long for a carbine. All solidly pre-war, anyway.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The bayonets also don't rule out Lee-Metfords. They could easily be 1888 sword bayonets.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Anyhow, the technology's all too indistinct to date this accurately. The architecture may provide something more useful.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/30100012: The stripes are a bit further up but the two NCOs could be wearing this style.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I was thinking Martini-Henry but wanted to do a bit of research before I put it in.  The Lee-Metford is a possibility and in fact they were used in some cases right up to 1914.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: According to Wiki the Martini-Henry was replaced by the Lee-Metford in 1888 and the LM was in turn replaced by the Lee-Enfield from 1895 on.  Some units who fought in the Boer War starting in 1899 were still using the LM though these were phased out during that conflict.  It would be reasonable to think therefore that since the almost certainly Lee-Metfords were still in use at this time that it is approx. 1899 to 1902-3?  The caveat is that when I was in the FCA in the early 60's we were still using adapted Mark II Lee-Enfields for initial training. (They had a .22 tube inserted into the .303 barrel for use in indoor ranges)  For this kind of training where there is the possibility that they were using out of date weapons for which ammunition was not readily available as accidental discharge would be highly unlikely.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I'm wondering about the machine guns on the tripods at the right. One seems to have a magazine sticking out from the left of the weapon...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
Blowing the picture up, the almost remind of Thompson submachine guns... That's about 1917... The way the butt of the gun is lower than the barrel, the barrel stops, then it drops a bit before the butt end starts.

If it's pre-WW1 we're dating this as, my best guess is the  Hotchkiss M1909 Benet-Mercie machine gun/Hotchkiss Mle 1909

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I doubt that they were machine guns Brian.  For rifle training and especially for recruits it was common to use a tripod the get the inexperienced to aim properly.  I was just surprised at the primitive tripods they were using, I would have expected something a bit more flexible and better made than those!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02], the best match for the rifles seen here at wikipedia is the Lee-Metford

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] They're rifles. They're on tripods made of three poles with a sandbag on top so there's various bits of sandbag and sling sticking out, which may look like a magazine.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I wonder if the tripods were being used as aids when adjusting the sights?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] That's the idea, the tripod renders the rifle rock steady and pretty rigid so that the recruit can set the sights on the target and the instructor can check them to see how close or off he is!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/foxglove] foxglove mentioned, it intrigues me the way the exercises are arranged around the square. While it seems unlikely that you'd have live fire exercises in an enclosed square at the best of times, every drill group is taking a bead on another group. I can only imagine that it's either staged for the photo, or the drills are purely on technique (focusing on how to hold the weapon in different stances). I wonder in fact whether the drills are being conducted in sequence. ("Prone firing from cover" drills are run first, then you move on to "firing with reduced profile", then "firing from fixed position", then some other handling or drills at the far side of the square)...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/foxglove] I'm voting for "staged for the camera" option!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
